qas.question: What will often add bopomofo phonetic symbols?
What may render certain names in katakana instead of kanji?

context: One man who has encountered this problem is Taiwanese politician <a0_0>Yu Shyi-kun<a0_0/>, due to the rarity of the last character in his name. Newspapers have dealt with this problem in varying ways, including using software to combine two existing, similar characters, including a picture of the personality, or, especially as is the case with Yu Shyi-kun, simply substituting a homophone for the rare character in the hope that the reader would be able to make the correct inference. Taiwanese political posters, <a1_0>movie posters<a1_0/> etc. will often add the bopomofo phonetic symbols next to such a character. <a2_0>Japanese newspapers<a2_0/> may render such names and words in katakana instead of kanji, and it is accepted practice for people to write names for which they are unsure of the correct kanji in katakana instead.
